Hi, 

as one of the autors of a test generator, I'd like to respond to the question frome Steve and a few of the answers from people in this
group.

Steve asked with regard to empty methods generated by 
test generators:

> > Is there a way to track the number of assertions that pass/fail
> > instead of the number of methods that are invoked in the test classes?
> >  This way the numbers reported (e.g., 122 tests run) would tend to
> > imply better test coverage, or at least more actual tests executing,
> > rather than lots of empty tests running.  (Yes, I know bad tests can


> I'm tempted to say that the generated tests is what you should look 
> into, rather than JUnit.  For example, if your generated test put 
> something like this into the body:
> 
> throw new Exception("Test Not Yet Implemented");
> 
> -shane
 

>    From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
> Then fix the test generator. I use an explicit failure to indicate that
> I have not yet written the test. In fact, in my "JUnit: A Starter
> Guide", I suggest starting with this test:
> 
> testSomething:
>     fail("Not yet implemented")
> 
> As I add code to the test, I keep the fail statement in there until I
> have decided that the test is complete.
> 
> It sounds to me like you should consider changing the test generator,
> and not JUnit, to solve your problem.

Why are there empty methods at all?
 
I know, that some of you practice TDD and are very active in the 
testdrivendevelopment list. Empty tests won't happen with TDD, 
at least not without any generator. ;-)

If you have at least a compilable skeleton of your application class,
tools like our JUnitDoclet or many others can generate a skeleton 
of TestCases - just the skeleton, not much flesh. So I'd like to
consider the generating as:
  Offering a place to fill in some tests very easy. 
(You may nee functional tests too, but that's of topic here.)
Any code generator will do that, after all that is what they are 
build for. If you don't fill in the tests, that is a different thing.

A generator could put fail(); in any empty tests very easy.
But there is a major downside too, especially for regenerating 
tools loke JUnitDoclet. I don't want to copy/paste half 
a page to this email, please see:
  http://www.junitdoclet.org/faq.html#fail_not_default 

Back to the question from Steve. 

He asked me the same thing directly as well. If I understand 
him right, he want's to measure his progress in writing tests 
for a given application. (With a generator, the number of 
tests is a constant as long as the application stays as it is.)

 * Counting the assertions is one option he came up with. 
    
 * I suggested the size of all tests as a very rough estimate
   to be another option. (Since I'm not payed by kbyte, 
   I prefer that way of measuring progress because of it's 
   simplicity.)

 * Test coverage tools are very likely the most precice option.

 * Removing empty methods as an additional step in building
   the tests could serve as an option too. (A simple script could 
   do that.) But the estimate is not much better than "size of
   all tests", isn't it? (You meight measure the number of tests 
   you've touched, but not the care you put into each test.)

Anyway, the next version of JUnitDoclet will report the number 
of empty methods each time it generates. Maybe we provide 
an option to list them too.  

I hope, this is was helpful to someone.

Kind Regards,

Steffen Gemkow
